content: Wear compression stockings to reduce swelling in your legs. Varicose veins and venous insufficiency can cause blood flow in your leg veins to slow, which results in swelling. Compression stockings can stimulate blood flow, improving circulation and reducing swelling. Wear compression stockings until you see a significant improvement in your legs, or as advised by your doctor. [1] Purchase compression stockings at medical supply stores or online. Be sure to remove your compression stockings at the end of each day to wash and dry them before wearing them again. [2] Elevate your legs above your heart when sitting or lying down at home. Raising your legs above your heart will reduce pain and pressure in your legs due to vein problems. Aim to have your feet at least 6 inches (15 cm) above your heart. Use pillows to prop up your legs if necessary. [3] Do this as often as you can, at home or in other relaxed locations such as the beach. Keep your legs cool to avoid worsening symptoms. Heat can cause increased blood flow in your blood vessels, making varicose veins and other vein problems worse. Avoid very hot showers and baths, sitting near a campfire or heater, or using a heat pack. If your legs feel hot, swollen, or hurt, apply a cool compress as needed to make them more comfortable. [4] Contact your doctor if you notice signs of serious vein damage. Some vein problems seem minor but may develop into a bigger problem. While milder issues like varicose veins, for instance, are sometimes just an aesthetic issue, they may also indicate a serious condition like deep vein thrombosis. See your doctor as soon as possible if you notice: [5] Swelling in your legs Intense calf pain Skin discoloration Open sores Dry, thin skin Speak to your doctor about taking horse chestnut seed extract. Studies have shown that taking horse chestnut seed extract orally can reduce the symptoms of vein problems like venous insufficiency after 2-16 weeks. Ask your doctor if it is safe to take this supplement. Follow the prescribed dose and contact your doctor if you experience any side effects, such as gastrointestinal distress or dizziness. [6] Buy horse chestnut seed extract at pharmacies, health stores, or online. Ask your doctor about taking medicine to treat damaged veins. Vasodilator medications can increase blood flow through the vessels, improving your circulation. [7] Ask your doctor if you can take one of these medicines as part of a vein repair treatment plan. A combination of compression therapy and medicine often proves effective. [8] Nitroglycerin and alprostadil are popular prescription vasodilators. Always take these medications exactly as they are prescribed. Ask your doctor about sclerotherapy to treat small varicose veins. Sclerotherapy involves inserting a small needle into varicose veins to inject them with substances like glycerin or hypertonic saline. This will collapse the varicose veins, reducing their physical appearance as well as the discomfort caused by them. Talk to your doctor about this treatment to see if it is right for you. [9] Results can usually be observed 3-6 weeks after the treatment. [10] Your doctor will usually book a follow-up appointment about a month after the sclerotherapy procedure to see if another session is needed. In some cases, varicose veins may return after this treatment. Talk to your doctor about thermal ablation to close off problem veins. Endovenous thermal ablation is a procedure that uses a laser or high-frequency radio waves to target damaged veins. The heat emitted shuts off the vein from the rest of the circulatory system without collapsing it. Talk to your doctor about this procedure if you want a long-term treatment option with minimal pain or healing time. [11] This treatment leaves the closed off veins in place, resulting in very little bruising or bleeding. Discuss your surgical options if all else fails. Most patients with vein problems do not need surgery to repair them, but the option still exists. If your veins are severely damaged, ask your doctor if surgery may be right for you. Your doctor might suggest: [12] Ligation and stripping, where a vascular surgeon will cuts and ties off your problem veins, or remove them. Micro-incision phlebectomy, where a surgeon will make small incisions or punctures in your veins and remove the problem ones with a phlebectomy hook. Vein bypass, where a piece of healthy vein is transplanted to reroute blood flow around a damaged vein. Do exercises that work your lower body on a regular basis. Exercising regularly can improve the strength of your legs and veins and improve your circulation. Exercises that focus on your legs, such as walking or running, are especially beneficial to help prevent the development of varicose veins or spider veins. [13] Aim to get 30 minutes or more of exercise everyday, or at least 150 minutes of aerobic activity per week. [14] Other forms of exercise, such as biking, swimming, rollerblading, and jumping rope, can also benefit the health of your veins. Avoid sitting or standing still for more than 30 minutes. Staying immobile for long periods of time causes your veins to work harder to pump blood to your heart, which may result in enlarged veins. Do your best to stay as active as possible throughout the day. If you are forced to stay in one spot for long periods of time, take a short walk or move your legs at least once every 30 minutes to maintain proper blood circulation in your body. [15] If you are travelling or attending a show, for example, get up to stretch your legs every 30 minutes or change your sitting or standing position frequently. Avoid using recreational intravenous drugs. The use of intravenous drugs outside of a prescribed medical treatment is extremely dangerous and and ill-advised. It can cause thrombosis and vein collapse as well as other health risks, such as infection. Avoid using intravenous drugs or seek help for your addiction if you are already using them. [16] Injecting drugs into the veins in your feet, groin, or neck is especially dangerous and may cause burst veins, excessive bleeding, abscesses, nerve damage, or stroke. Be sure to avoid using any collapsed veins. For a list of treatment services in your state, visit /drug-abuse-programs/ . Always use new, sharp needles if you inject drugs. If you are injecting drugs, never re-use a needle. In addition to a heightened risk of infection, a needle that has dulled after several uses is more likely to cause trauma to your vein. Use a a new, sterile needle for every single injection. [17] Dispose of your needle safely after using it to avoid causing injury to others.

<p>There are numerous ways that you can repair damaged veins, ranging from at-home treatments to medical procedures. Mild conditions like varicose veins can be improved by taking small measures such as wearing compression socks and elevating your feet. For more intense damage, ask your doctor about medication, non-invasive procedures, and surgeries to repair your veins.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Applying_Immediate_Treatments_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Applying_Immediate_Treatments">Applying Immediate Treatments</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Dress-Professionally-Step-14-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=10068301" href="#/Image:Dress-Professionally-Step-14-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Dress Professionally Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Dress-Professionally-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Dress-Professionally-Step-14-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_a967cec72d" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a967cec72d')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Dress Professionally Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Dress-Professionally-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Dress-Professionally-Step-14-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Wear compression stockings to reduce swelling in your legs.</b> Varicose veins and venous insufficiency can cause blood flow in your leg veins to slow, which results in swelling. Compression stockings can stimulate blood flow, improving circulation and reducing swelling. Wear compression stockings until you see a significant improvement in your legs, or as advised by your doctor.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Purchase compression stockings at medical supply stores or online.</li>
<li>Be sure to remove your compression stockings at the end of each day to wash and dry them before wearing them again.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Reduce-Water-Retention-Step-11-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=10068301" href="#/Image:Reduce-Water-Retention-Step-11-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Reduce Water Retention Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ac/Reduce-Water-Retention-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Reduce-Water-Retention-Step-11-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_2f2691f81a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_2f2691f81a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Reduce Water Retention Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ac/Reduce-Water-Retention-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Reduce-Water-Retention-Step-11-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Elevate your legs above your heart when sitting or lying down at home.</b> Raising your legs above your heart will reduce pain and pressure in your legs due to vein problems. Aim to have your feet at least 6 inches (15 cm) above your heart. Use pillows to prop up your legs if necessary.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Do this as often as you can, at home or in other relaxed locations such as the beach.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Treat-a-Cramped-Muscle-Step-2-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=10068301" href="#/Image:Treat-a-Cramped-Muscle-Step-2-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Treat a Cramped Muscle Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/95/Treat-a-Cramped-Muscle-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Treat-a-Cramped-Muscle-Step-2-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_c91d318b1f" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c91d318b1f')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Treat a Cramped Muscle Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/95/Treat-a-Cramped-Muscle-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Treat-a-Cramped-Muscle-Step-2-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Keep your legs cool to avoid worsening symptoms.</b> Heat can cause increased blood flow in your blood vessels, making varicose veins and other vein problems worse. Avoid very hot showers and baths, sitting near a campfire or heater, or using a heat pack. If your legs feel hot, swollen, or hurt, apply a cool compress as needed to make them more comfortable.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Physical-Therapy-to-Recover-From-Surgery-Step-1-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=10068301" href="#/Image:Use-Physical-Therapy-to-Recover-From-Surgery-Step-1-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Physical Therapy to Recover From Surgery Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5d/Use-Physical-Therapy-to-Recover-From-Surgery-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Use-Physical-Therapy-to-Recover-From-Surgery-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_c9bdcf8adc" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c9bdcf8adc')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Physical Therapy to Recover From Surgery Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5d/Use-Physical-Therapy-to-Recover-From-Surgery-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Use-Physical-Therapy-to-Recover-From-Surgery-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Contact your doctor if you notice signs of serious vein damage.</b> Some vein problems seem minor but may develop into a bigger problem. While milder issues like varicose veins, for instance, are sometimes just an aesthetic issue, they may also indicate a serious condition like deep vein thrombosis. See your doctor as soon as possible if you notice:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Swelling in your legs</li>
<li>Intense calf pain</li>
<li>Skin discoloration</li>
<li>Open sores</li>
<li>Dry, thin skin</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>

</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Looking_into_Long-Term_Solutions_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Looking_into_Long-Term_Solutions">Looking into Long-Term Solutions</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Treat-Low-Testosterone-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=10068301" href="#/Image:Treat-Low-Testosterone-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Treat Low Testosterone Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/28/Treat-Low-Testosterone-Step-9.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Treat-Low-Testosterone-Step-9.jpg" height="546" id="img_ceac79dcfe" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ceac79dcfe')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Treat Low Testosterone Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/28/Treat-Low-Testosterone-Step-9.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Treat-Low-Testosterone-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Speak to your doctor about taking horse chestnut seed extract.</b> Studies have shown that taking horse chestnut seed extract orally can reduce the symptoms of vein problems like venous insufficiency after 2-16 weeks. Ask your doctor if it is safe to take this supplement. Follow the prescribed dose and contact your doctor if you experience any side effects, such as gastrointestinal distress or dizziness.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Buy horse chestnut seed extract at pharmacies, health stores, or online.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Treat-Alzheimer%27s-Disease-Step-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=10068301" href="#/Image:Treat-Alzheimer%27s-Disease-Step-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Treat Alzheimer's Disease Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Treat-Alzheimer%27s-Disease-Step-4.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Treat-Alzheimer%27s-Disease-Step-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_b511d39a61" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b511d39a61')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Treat Alzheimer's Disease Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Treat-Alzheimer%27s-Disease-Step-4.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Treat-Alzheimer%27s-Disease-Step-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Ask your doctor about taking medicine to treat damaged veins.</b> Vasodilator medications can increase blood flow through the vessels, improving your circulation.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup> Ask your doctor if you can take one of these medicines as part of a vein repair treatment plan. A combination of compression therapy and medicine often proves effective.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Nitroglycerin and alprostadil are popular prescription vasodilators.</li>
<li>Always take these medications exactly as they are prescribed.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Sclerotherapy-for-Spider-Veins-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=10068301" href="#/Image:Get-Sclerotherapy-for-Spider-Veins-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Sclerotherapy for Spider Veins Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Get-Sclerotherapy-for-Spider-Veins-Step-9.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Get-Sclerotherapy-for-Spider-Veins-Step-9.jpg" height="546" id="img_2a37eff623" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_2a37eff623')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Sclerotherapy for Spider Veins Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Get-Sclerotherapy-for-Spider-Veins-Step-9.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Get-Sclerotherapy-for-Spider-Veins-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Ask your doctor about sclerotherapy to treat small varicose veins.</b> Sclerotherapy involves inserting a small needle into varicose veins to inject them with substances like glycerin or hypertonic saline. This will collapse the varicose veins, reducing their physical appearance as well as the discomfort caused by them. Talk to your doctor about this treatment to see if it is right for you.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Results can usually be observed 3-6 weeks after the treatment.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Your doctor will usually book a follow-up appointment about a month after the sclerotherapy procedure to see if another session is needed.</li>
<li>In some cases, varicose veins may return after this treatment.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Increase-Breast-Size-Step-15.jpg?ajax=true&aid=10068301" href="#/Image:Increase-Breast-Size-Step-15.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Increase Breast Size Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/00/Increase-Breast-Size-Step-15.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Increase-Breast-Size-Step-15.jpg" height="546" id="img_05c86947cb" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_05c86947cb')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Increase Breast Size Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/00/Increase-Breast-Size-Step-15.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Increase-Breast-Size-Step-15.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Talk to your doctor about thermal ablation to close off problem veins.</b> Endovenous thermal ablation is a procedure that uses a laser or high-frequency radio waves to target damaged veins. The heat emitted shuts off the vein from the rest of the circulatory system without collapsing it. Talk to your doctor about this procedure if you want a long-term treatment option with minimal pain or healing time.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>This treatment leaves the closed off veins in place, resulting in very little bruising or bleeding.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Treat-Upper-Back-Pain-Step-10-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=10068301" href="#/Image:Treat-Upper-Back-Pain-Step-10-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Treat Upper Back Pain Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bb/Treat-Upper-Back-Pain-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Treat-Upper-Back-Pain-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_94448a4fbc" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_94448a4fbc')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Treat Upper Back Pain Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bb/Treat-Upper-Back-Pain-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Treat-Upper-Back-Pain-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Discuss your surgical options if all else fails.</b> Most patients with vein problems do not need surgery to repair them, but the option still exists. If your veins are severely damaged, ask your doctor if surgery may be right for you. Your doctor might suggest:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Ligation and stripping, where a vascular surgeon will cuts and ties off your problem veins, or remove them.</li>
<li>Micro-incision phlebectomy, where a surgeon will make small incisions or punctures in your veins and remove the problem ones with a phlebectomy hook.</li>
<li>Vein bypass, where a piece of healthy vein is transplanted to reroute blood flow around a damaged vein.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Preventing_Vein_Damage_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Preventing_Vein_Damage">Preventing Vein Damage</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Strengthen-Hips-with-Exercise-Step-1.jpg?ajax=true&aid=10068301" href="#/Image:Strengthen-Hips-with-Exercise-Step-1.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Strengthen Hips with Exercise Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e7/Strengthen-Hips-with-Exercise-Step-1.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Strengthen-Hips-with-Exercise-Step-1.jpg" height="546" id="img_7629eb9ad3" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7629eb9ad3')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Strengthen Hips with Exercise Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e7/Strengthen-Hips-with-Exercise-Step-1.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Strengthen-Hips-with-Exercise-Step-1.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Do exercises that work your lower body on a regular basis.</b> Exercising regularly can improve the strength of your legs and veins and improve your circulation. Exercises that focus on your legs, such as walking or running, are especially beneficial to help prevent the development of varicose veins or spider veins.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup> Aim to get 30 minutes or more of exercise everyday, or at least 150 minutes of aerobic activity per week.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Other forms of exercise, such as biking, swimming, rollerblading, and jumping rope, can also benefit the health of your veins.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Treat-Upper-Back-Pain-Step-1-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=10068301" href="#/Image:Treat-Upper-Back-Pain-Step-1-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Treat Upper Back Pain Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Treat-Upper-Back-Pain-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Treat-Upper-Back-Pain-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_ef2ec7ae35" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ef2ec7ae35')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Treat Upper Back Pain Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Treat-Upper-Back-Pain-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Treat-Upper-Back-Pain-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Avoid sitting or standing still for more than 30 minutes.</b> Staying immobile for long periods of time causes your veins to work harder to pump blood to your heart, which may result in enlarged veins. Do your best to stay as active as possible throughout the day. If you are forced to stay in one spot for long periods of time, take a short walk or move your legs at least once every 30 minutes to maintain proper blood circulation in your body.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>If you are travelling or attending a show, for example, get up to stretch your legs every 30 minutes or change your sitting or standing position frequently.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Bigger-Naturally-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=10068301" href="#/Image:Get-Bigger-Naturally-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Bigger Naturally Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Get-Bigger-Naturally-Step-12.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Get-Bigger-Naturally-Step-12.jpg" height="546" id="img_497fb462f2" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_497fb462f2')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Bigger Naturally Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Get-Bigger-Naturally-Step-12.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Get-Bigger-Naturally-Step-12.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Avoid using recreational intravenous drugs.</b> The use of intravenous drugs outside of a prescribed medical treatment is extremely dangerous and and ill-advised. It can cause thrombosis and vein collapse as well as other health risks, such as infection. Avoid using intravenous drugs or seek help for your addiction if you are already using them.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Injecting drugs into the veins in your feet, groin, or neck is especially dangerous and may cause burst veins, excessive bleeding, abscesses, nerve damage, or stroke.</li>
<li>Be sure to avoid using any collapsed veins.</li>
<li>For a list of treatment services in your state, visit <a class="external free" href="https://drugabuse.com/drug-abuse-programs/" rel="nofollow">https://drugabuse.com/drug-abuse-programs/</a>.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Increase-Platelets-Step-6.jpg?ajax=true&aid=10068301" href="#/Image:Increase-Platelets-Step-6.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Increase Platelets Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Increase-Platelets-Step-6.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Increase-Platelets-Step-6.jpg" height="546" id="img_88c536047f" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_88c536047f')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Increase Platelets Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Increase-Platelets-Step-6.jpg/aid10068301-v4-728px-Increase-Platelets-Step-6.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Always use new, sharp needles if you inject drugs.</b> If you are injecting drugs, never re-use a needle. In addition to a heightened risk of infection, a needle that has dulled after several uses is more likely to cause trauma to your vein. Use a a new, sterile needle for every single injection.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Dispose of your needle safely after using it to avoid causing injury to others.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>

    "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",

        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/24\/Increase-Platelets-Step-6.jpg\/aid10068301-v4-1200px-Increase-Platelets-Step-6.jpg",
        "width": 1200,

    },
    "author": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",

    "publisher": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",

            "@type": "ImageObject",
            "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/skins\/owl\/images\/wikihow_logo_name_green_60.png",
            "width": 326,
            "height": 60
        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",
            "https:\/\/twitter.com\/wikiHow",
            "https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/company\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/user\/WikiHow"
        ]
    },
    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Applying Immediate Treatments",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Wear compression stockings to reduce swelling in your legs. Varicose veins and venous insufficiency can cause blood flow in your leg veins to slow, which results in swelling. Compression stockings can stimulate blood flow, improving circulation and reducing swelling. Wear compression stockings until you see a significant improvement in your legs, or as advised by your doctor.[1]\nPurchase compression stockings at medical supply stores or online.\nBe sure to remove your compression stockings at the end of each day to wash and dry them before wearing them again.[2]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Elevate your legs above your heart when sitting or lying down at home. Raising your legs above your heart will reduce pain and pressure in your legs due to vein problems. Aim to have your feet at least 6 inches (15\u00a0cm) above your heart. Use pillows to prop up your legs if necessary.[3]\nDo this as often as you can, at home or in other relaxed locations such as the beach."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Keep your legs cool to avoid worsening symptoms. Heat can cause increased blood flow in your blood vessels, making varicose veins and other vein problems worse. Avoid very hot showers and baths, sitting near a campfire or heater, or using a heat pack. If your legs feel hot, swollen, or hurt, apply a cool compress as needed to make them more comfortable.[4]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Contact your doctor if you notice signs of serious vein damage. Some vein problems seem minor but may develop into a bigger problem. While milder issues like varicose veins, for instance, are sometimes just an aesthetic issue, they may also indicate a serious condition like deep vein thrombosis. See your doctor as soon as possible if you notice:[5]\nSwelling in your legs\nIntense calf pain\nSkin discoloration\nOpen sores\nDry, thin skin"
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Looking into Long-Term Solutions",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Speak to your doctor about taking horse chestnut seed extract. Studies have shown that taking horse chestnut seed extract orally can reduce the symptoms of vein problems like venous insufficiency after 2-16 weeks. Ask your doctor if it is safe to take this supplement. Follow the prescribed dose and contact your doctor if you experience any side effects, such as gastrointestinal distress or dizziness.[6]\nBuy horse chestnut seed extract at pharmacies, health stores, or online."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Ask your doctor about taking medicine to treat damaged veins. Vasodilator medications can increase blood flow through the vessels, improving your circulation.[7] Ask your doctor if you can take one of these medicines as part of a vein repair treatment plan. A combination of compression therapy and medicine often proves effective.[8]\nNitroglycerin and alprostadil are popular prescription vasodilators.\nAlways take these medications exactly as they are prescribed."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Ask your doctor about sclerotherapy to treat small varicose veins. Sclerotherapy involves inserting a small needle into varicose veins to inject them with substances like glycerin or hypertonic saline. This will collapse the varicose veins, reducing their physical appearance as well as the discomfort caused by them. Talk to your doctor about this treatment to see if it is right for you.[9]\nResults can usually be observed 3-6 weeks after the treatment.[10]\nYour doctor will usually book a follow-up appointment about a month after the sclerotherapy procedure to see if another session is needed.\nIn some cases, varicose veins may return after this treatment."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Talk to your doctor about thermal ablation to close off problem veins. Endovenous thermal ablation is a procedure that uses a laser or high-frequency radio waves to target damaged veins. The heat emitted shuts off the vein from the rest of the circulatory system without collapsing it. Talk to your doctor about this procedure if you want a long-term treatment option with minimal pain or healing time.[11]\nThis treatment leaves the closed off veins in place, resulting in very little bruising or bleeding."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Discuss your surgical options if all else fails. Most patients with vein problems do not need surgery to repair them, but the option still exists. If your veins are severely damaged, ask your doctor if surgery may be right for you. Your doctor might suggest:[12]\nLigation and stripping, where a vascular surgeon will cuts and ties off your problem veins, or remove them.\nMicro-incision phlebectomy, where a surgeon will make small incisions or punctures in your veins and remove the problem ones with a phlebectomy hook.\nVein bypass, where a piece of healthy vein is transplanted to reroute blood flow around a damaged vein."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Preventing Vein Damage",
            "position": 3,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Do exercises that work your lower body on a regular basis. Exercising regularly can improve the strength of your legs and veins and improve your circulation. Exercises that focus on your legs, such as walking or running, are especially beneficial to help prevent the development of varicose veins or spider veins.[13] Aim to get 30 minutes or more of exercise everyday, or at least 150 minutes of aerobic activity per week.[14]\nOther forms of exercise, such as biking, swimming, rollerblading, and jumping rope, can also benefit the health of your veins."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Avoid sitting or standing still for more than 30 minutes. Staying immobile for long periods of time causes your veins to work harder to pump blood to your heart, which may result in enlarged veins. Do your best to stay as active as possible throughout the day. If you are forced to stay in one spot for long periods of time, take a short walk or move your legs at least once every 30 minutes to maintain proper blood circulation in your body.[15]\nIf you are travelling or attending a show, for example, get up to stretch your legs every 30 minutes or change your sitting or standing position frequently."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Avoid using recreational intravenous drugs. The use of intravenous drugs outside of a prescribed medical treatment is extremely dangerous and and ill-advised. It can cause thrombosis and vein collapse as well as other health risks, such as infection. Avoid using intravenous drugs or seek help for your addiction if you are already using them.[16]\nInjecting drugs into the veins in your feet, groin, or neck is especially dangerous and may cause burst veins, excessive bleeding, abscesses, nerve damage, or stroke.\nBe sure to avoid using any collapsed veins.\nFor a list of treatment services in your state, visit https:\/\/drugabuse.com\/drug-abuse-programs\/."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Always use new, sharp needles if you inject drugs. If you are injecting drugs, never re-use a needle. In addition to a heightened risk of infection, a needle that has dulled after several uses is more likely to cause trauma to your vein. Use a a new, sterile needle for every single injection.[17]\nDispose of your needle safely after using it to avoid causing injury to others."
                    }
                }
            ]
        }
    ],
    "description": "How to Repair Damaged Veins. There are numerous ways that you can repair damaged veins, ranging from at-home treatments to medical procedures. Mild conditions like varicose veins can be improved by taking small measures such as wearing..."

title: How to Repair Damaged Veins
content_html:
Wear compression stockings to reduce swelling in your legs. Varicose veins and venous insufficiency can cause blood flow in your leg veins to slow, which results in swelling. Compression stockings can stimulate blood flow, improving circulation and reducing swelling. Wear compression stockings until you see a significant improvement in your legs, or as advised by your doctor.[1]
  • Purchase compression stockings at medical supply stores or online.
  • Be sure to remove your compression stockings at the end of each day to wash and dry them before wearing them again.[2]
Elevate your legs above your heart when sitting or lying down at home. Raising your legs above your heart will reduce pain and pressure in your legs due to vein problems. Aim to have your feet at least 6 inches (15 cm) above your heart. Use pillows to prop up your legs if necessary.[3]
  • Do this as often as you can, at home or in other relaxed locations such as the beach.
Keep your legs cool to avoid worsening symptoms. Heat can cause increased blood flow in your blood vessels, making varicose veins and other vein problems worse. Avoid very hot showers and baths, sitting near a campfire or heater, or using a heat pack. If your legs feel hot, swollen, or hurt, apply a cool compress as needed to make them more comfortable.[4]
Contact your doctor if you notice signs of serious vein damage. Some vein problems seem minor but may develop into a bigger problem. While milder issues like varicose veins, for instance, are sometimes just an aesthetic issue, they may also indicate a serious condition like deep vein thrombosis. See your doctor as soon as possible if you notice:[5]
  • Swelling in your legs
  • Intense calf pain
  • Skin discoloration
  • Open sores
  • Dry, thin skin
Speak to your doctor about taking horse chestnut seed extract. Studies have shown that taking horse chestnut seed extract orally can reduce the symptoms of vein problems like venous insufficiency after 2-16 weeks. Ask your doctor if it is safe to take this supplement. Follow the prescribed dose and contact your doctor if you experience any side effects, such as gastrointestinal distress or dizziness.[6]
  • Buy horse chestnut seed extract at pharmacies, health stores, or online.
Ask your doctor about taking medicine to treat damaged veins. Vasodilator medications can increase blood flow through the vessels, improving your circulation.[7] Ask your doctor if you can take one of these medicines as part of a vein repair treatment plan. A combination of compression therapy and medicine often proves effective.[8]
  • Nitroglycerin and alprostadil are popular prescription vasodilators.
  • Always take these medications exactly as they are prescribed.
Ask your doctor about sclerotherapy to treat small varicose veins. Sclerotherapy involves inserting a small needle into varicose veins to inject them with substances like glycerin or hypertonic saline. This will collapse the varicose veins, reducing their physical appearance as well as the discomfort caused by them. Talk to your doctor about this treatment to see if it is right for you.[9]
  • Results can usually be observed 3-6 weeks after the treatment.[10]
  • Your doctor will usually book a follow-up appointment about a month after the sclerotherapy procedure to see if another session is needed.
  • In some cases, varicose veins may return after this treatment.
Talk to your doctor about thermal ablation to close off problem veins. Endovenous thermal ablation is a procedure that uses a laser or high-frequency radio waves to target damaged veins. The heat emitted shuts off the vein from the rest of the circulatory system without collapsing it. Talk to your doctor about this procedure if you want a long-term treatment option with minimal pain or healing time.[11]
  • This treatment leaves the closed off veins in place, resulting in very little bruising or bleeding.
Discuss your surgical options if all else fails. Most patients with vein problems do not need surgery to repair them, but the option still exists. If your veins are severely damaged, ask your doctor if surgery may be right for you. Your doctor might suggest:[12]
  • Ligation and stripping, where a vascular surgeon will cuts and ties off your problem veins, or remove them.
  • Micro-incision phlebectomy, where a surgeon will make small incisions or punctures in your veins and remove the problem ones with a phlebectomy hook.
  • Vein bypass, where a piece of healthy vein is transplanted to reroute blood flow around a damaged vein.
Do exercises that work your lower body on a regular basis. Exercising regularly can improve the strength of your legs and veins and improve your circulation. Exercises that focus on your legs, such as walking or running, are especially beneficial to help prevent the development of varicose veins or spider veins.[13] Aim to get 30 minutes or more of exercise everyday, or at least 150 minutes of aerobic activity per week.[14]
  • Other forms of exercise, such as biking, swimming, rollerblading, and jumping rope, can also benefit the health of your veins.
Avoid sitting or standing still for more than 30 minutes. Staying immobile for long periods of time causes your veins to work harder to pump blood to your heart, which may result in enlarged veins. Do your best to stay as active as possible throughout the day. If you are forced to stay in one spot for long periods of time, take a short walk or move your legs at least once every 30 minutes to maintain proper blood circulation in your body.[15]
  • If you are travelling or attending a show, for example, get up to stretch your legs every 30 minutes or change your sitting or standing position frequently.
Avoid using recreational intravenous drugs. The use of intravenous drugs outside of a prescribed medical treatment is extremely dangerous and and ill-advised. It can cause thrombosis and vein collapse as well as other health risks, such as infection. Avoid using intravenous drugs or seek help for your addiction if you are already using them.[16]
  • Injecting drugs into the veins in your feet, groin, or neck is especially dangerous and may cause burst veins, excessive bleeding, abscesses, nerve damage, or stroke.
  • Be sure to avoid using any collapsed veins.
  • For a list of treatment services in your state, visit https://drugabuse.com/drug-abuse-programs/.
Always use new, sharp needles if you inject drugs. If you are injecting drugs, never re-use a needle. In addition to a heightened risk of infection, a needle that has dulled after several uses is more likely to cause trauma to your vein. Use a a new, sterile needle for every single injection.[17]
  • Dispose of your needle safely after using it to avoid causing injury to others.
